title: Fox and Friends Segment Suggests Climate Change is the Result of Friction
text:
Earlier this week, Eric Bolling and Tucker Carlson broadcast a very heated segment on climate change on Fox News. They started with arguing over the planet's total energy consumption and shifted it over to the question of how long we've been warming and to the current tension over climate change. Given the dire warnings by governments around the world, the segment, which was hosted by Bret Baier, drew boos from the Fox audience. Early in the segment, Carlson suggested climate change was not natural, and that it was "really building up steam." In fact, there's a pretty wide consensus on the fact that climate change is what happens when the Earth's climate gets too hot or too cold, and this is largely in large part a result of our over-all population growth. [Note to Fox News: Please, please, please not make human births more likely as a result of one spike in population.] While some tech-savvy folks in the audience had tried to amplify Carlson's calls, others booed him at every possible second before he spoke. One woman talked about how her child used to ask if she should go to bed. As one viewer commented, the feedback from these moderators can make him or her feel as if they have to change the subject, something that has happened to Nielsen ratings. In this environment, Eric Bolling should be applauded for trying to highlight Fox News' hostility toward him. More recently, a segment on Fox News' Townhall website showed a man wearing a "Jihad" button and asking questions about Islam. And most recently, Bret Baier's show featured an alleged suspect in the San Bernardino, California, mass shooting, noting that her Twitter account "has a large number of followers and a lot of followers." Baier then pointed out that a website was used to post the tweets about her, and at the time of her show, her Twitter feed contained the same tweet. He went on to mention, though, that that's "biohazard [a term used in the ISIS propaganda].”
These conversations are entertaining in their own way and there will be times when the discussion between viewers and hosts can get heated. But these shouldn't be representative of public discussion of climate change. Doubtless the comments from some on Fox News will not be representative of public discourse on the topic. But they should not be the focus of discussion at all. There is not enough information out there about climate change to make the calculations for ourselves. We shouldn't be forced to rely on our instinct to know when something is climate friendly or climate negligent.
label: human
